# Admin UI 디자인 및 구현 (2025-12-26 10:49Z)

_**User (2025-12-26 06:40Z)**_

[프로젝트 목표]
- DashStack 캡처(라이트/다크)와 최대한 동일한 느낌의 Admin UI를 만든다.
- Next.js + TypeScript + Tailwind + shadcn/ui 기반(React).
- 라이트/다크 테마, 사이드바 접힘/펼침, KO/ZH i18n(언어 토글) 지원.
- 첨부된 로고/아이콘/파비콘을 실제 레이아웃에 적용한다.

[첨부될 디자인 레퍼런스(이미지)]
- DashStack 레이아웃 캡처(라이트/다크, Order Lists / Product Stock, 사이드바 펼침/접힘)가 여러 장 첨부된다.@capture 
- 반드시 캡처를 픽셀 레퍼런스처럼 최대한 가깝게 재현한다(여백, 라운드, 그림자, 타이포, 구분선, 테이블 밀도).

[브랜딩 에셋(첨부 파일 그대로 사용)]
| 모드 | 메뉴 상태 | 파일명
|-----|-----|-----
| 라이트 | 펼침 | `catsworks-logo-h120.png`
| 라이트 | 접힘 | `catsworks-icon-120.png`
| 다크 | 펼침 | `catsworks-logo-darkmode-fixed.png`
| 다크 | 접힘 | `catsworks-icon-120-darkmode-tailwhite.png`
- favicon: favicon.ico
@logo 
[디자인 테마: Modern Minimal]

[핵심 원칙]
- 깔끔한 중성 그레이스케일 색상 팔레트
- 얇은 아이콘 선 굵기 (strokeWidth: 1.5)
- 작은 border-radius (0.25rem ~ 0.5rem)
- 가벼운 폰트 굵기
- 미묘한 호버 효과
- 미니멀한 그림자 사용

[Primary 컬러]
- 메인 컬러: `#3EB991` (Teal/Emerald)
- OKLCH 변환값: `oklch(0.696 0.17 162.48)`

[폰트 시스템: Asia Gothic]
**폰트 파일 (4종 첨부 예정):**
@fonts 
- `a-asiagothic-light.woff2` (weight: 300)
- `a-asiagothic-medium.woff2` (weight: 500)
- `a-asiagothic-bold.woff2` (weight: 700)
- `a-asiagothic-extrabold.woff2` (weight: 800)

[폰트 적용 규칙 (중요도 기반)]

| 중요도 | 웨이트 | 적용 영역
|-----|-----|-----
| 일반 | Light (300) | 테이블 데이터, 설명문, 필터바 텍스트, 2단계 메뉴, Select/Input 텍스트
| 중간 제목 | Medium (500) | 1단계 메뉴, 버튼, 폼 라벨, 카드 서브타이틀, 배지
| 큰 제목 | Bold (700) | 페이지 헤더 타이틀, 통계 숫자, 테이블 헤더, 카드 타이틀
| 최대 제목 | ExtraBold (800) | 메인 대시보드 큰 타이틀, 최상위 강조 텍스트


[레이아웃 공통]
1) App Shell
- 좌측: Sidebar
- 상단: Topbar(검색, 알림, 언어 토글, 프로필)
- 본문: 페이지 컨텐츠(타이틀 + 페이지 액션 아이콘(하위메뉴) + 카드/테이블)

2) 사이드바 크기
- 펼침 상태: `205px`
- 접힘 상태: `62px`
- 트랜지션: `transition-all duration-300 ease-in-out`

3) Topbar
- 좌측: (collapsed 토글 버튼) + 검색 input
- 우측: 알림(배지), 언어 토글(ko/zh), 테마 토글(light/dark), 유저 드롭다운

4) 테마
- light: DashStack처럼 밝은 배경 + 흰 카드 + 연한 보더
- dark: 진한 슬레이트/네이비 계열 배경 + 카드/테이블이 떠 보이되 과한 그림자 금지
- 모든 컴포넌트는 테마에 따라 자연스럽게 색이 바뀌도록 CSS 변수/토큰 구조로

[i18n 규칙(필수)]
- 현재 언어 상태: lang = 'ko' | 'zh'
- 사이드바 메뉴명/페이지 타이틀/버튼 라벨/테이블 컬럼명은 모두 lang에 따라 변환
- “Order Lists(사입목록)” 테이블 컬럼은 아래 스키마의 labelKo/labelZh를 사용
- 테이블 헤더는 “엑셀처럼 2줄 금지” → 항상 한 줄(truncate 가능)

[메뉴 IA(실제 구조, 추후 확장 가능)]
- 대시보드
- 주문관리
  - 주문입력 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 업로드)
  - 사입목록 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 다운로드)  ← DashStack Order Lists 레이아웃 적용(핵심)
  - 제작상품 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 다운로드)
  - 입고목록 (페이지 상단 액션: 바코드 출력, 엑셀 다운로드)
  - 배송현황 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 다운로드)
- 상품관리 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 다운로드) ← DashStack Product Stock 레이아웃 적용(핵심)
- 중국업무
  - 인보이스 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 업로드, 엑셀 다운로드)
  - K&B정산 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 업로드, 엑셀 다운로드)
  - 업체정산 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 다운로드)
- 입금확인 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 다운로드)
- 교환환불 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 업로드, 엑셀 다운로드)
- 배송조회 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 업로드, 엑셀 다운로드)
- 마케팅 리포트 (페이지 상단 액션: 엑셀 업로드, 엑셀 다운로드)

[메뉴 구조]
├── 로고 영역 (h-16, border-b)
├── 네비게이션 영역 (flex-1, overflow-y-auto, p-2.5)
│   ├── 1단계 메뉴 (font-asia-medium, text-sm)
│   │   └── 2단계 메뉴 (font-asia-light, text-xs, pl-9)
└── 하단 영역 (user info, collapse button)

[메뉴 스타일]
- 1단계 메뉴: `font-asia-medium`, `text-sm`, 아이콘 `strokeWidth={1.5}`
- 2단계 메뉴: `font-asia-light`, `text-xs`, 왼쪽 패딩 `pl-9`
- 활성 메뉴: `bg-primary/10`, `text-primary`, `border-l-2 border-primary`
- 호버: `hover:bg-muted`


[UI 컴포넌트 스타일]
**버튼:**

- 기본: `font-asia-medium`
- Primary: `bg-primary text-primary-foreground hover:bg-primary/90`
- Outline: `border border-input bg-background hover:bg-accent`
- Ghost: `hover:bg-accent hover:text-accent-foreground`

**배지:**
- `font-asia-medium text-xs`
- 상태별 색상 (성공: green, 경고: yellow, 에러: red, 정보: blue)

**입력 필드:**
- `font-asia-light`
- `border-input bg-background`
- `focus:ring-2 focus:ring-primary/20`

**Select:**
- Trigger: `font-asia-light`
- Item: `font-asia-light`

[아이콘 스타일]
- 라이브러리: Lucide React
- 기본 크기: `w-4 h-4` 또는 `w-5 h-5`
- 선 굵기: `strokeWidth={1.5}` (Modern Minimal 스타일)


[페이지 상단 “하위메뉴(액션)” 표현 규칙]
- 각 페이지 타이틀 아래(테이블 위)에 아이콘 버튼 형태로 노출
- 예: [엑셀 업로드] [엑셀 다운로드] [바코드 출력] 등
- 아이콘+텍스트(한 줄), 툴팁 포함, 테마 대응

========================================================
[핵심 페이지 1] Order Lists = CatsWorks “사입목록”
- DashStack Order Lists 화면과 동일한 구조로 구현(카드, 필터 바, 테이블, 페이지네이션).
- 필터 바: Date / Order Type / Order Status / Reset Filter(캡처처럼)
  (실제 필터 로직은 더미로 두되 UI는 완성)
- 테이블은 가로 스크롤 허용(컬럼 29개), 헤더 sticky.
- 첫 컬럼(날짜) 또는 날짜+사진은 sticky(선택)해도 좋다(사용성 향상).

[Order Lists 테이블: “헤더 1행” 강제 + 그룹 시각 구분(필수)]
- thead는 1행만 사용(그룹 라벨용 추가 헤더 행 금지).
- 대신 아래 방식으로 그룹을 시각적으로 구분:
  1) 컬럼 그룹별 “세로 밴딩 배경” (header + body 동일한 아주 미세한 톤 차이)
  2) 그룹 시작 컬럼에만 얇은 vertical divider(보더) 추가: B, H, P, W, AA 앞
  3) 테이블 상단에 “그룹 레전드 칩(기타/자사/업체/구매/예약)” 표시(색/톤은 밴딩과 매칭)
  4) 각 th에는 title로 그룹명 제공(예: title="자사 정보"), 하지만 텍스트는 컬럼명 1줄만 노출

[컬럼 그룹 규칙]
- 기타: A, AA~AC
- 자사 정보: B~G
- 업체 정보: H~O
- 구매 정보: P~V
- 예약정보: W~Z
[Order Lists 컬럼 스키마(파일 없이 고정, 그대로 사용)]
- columns 배열을 그대로 사용해 테이블 컬럼을 정의한다.
- 표시 라벨: lang==='ko'이면 labelKo, lang==='zh'이면 labelZh
- key는 그대로 사용(데이터 row 매핑용)

- 아래 12행을 그대로 테이블에 표시(키는 위 columns의 key와 매칭)

[Order Lists 셀/컬럼 표현 가이드]
- 사진(cb): 썸네일(없으면 placeholder)
- URL(cc), 구매URL(ch): 링크 아이콘 + 클릭 가능(길면 ellipsis)
- 원가(₩)(cg), 원가(￥)(co): 통화 포맷(우측 정렬)
- 주문수량(cp) 등 수량: 숫자(가운데 또는 우측)
- 바코드(caa): monospace + 복사 버튼
- 셀메이트번호(cab): 숫자
- 담당자(cac): 텍스트
========================================================
[핵심 페이지 2] Product Stock = CatsWorks “상품관리”(또는 “제작상품”)
- DashStack Product Stock 캡처처럼: 상단 우측 검색, 썸네일 포함 테이블, row actions(편집/삭제).
- 컬럼 예시: Image / Product Name / Category / Price / Piece(재고) / Available Color / Action
- Available Color: 컬러 도트(tooltip)
- Action: 아이콘 버튼(편집/삭제), hover 상태 캡처처럼

========================================================
[구현 산출물 요구]
- 라우팅: 메뉴 클릭 시 해당 페이지로 이동(더미 라우트 OK)
- 컴포넌트: AppShell, Sidebar(접힘/펼침), Topbar, PageHeader(타이틀+액션아이콘), DataTable(가로스크롤+sticky header)
- 테이블 헤더는 1행만 사용(중요).
- 그룹 시각 구분은 “밴딩 배경 + 그룹 경계 divider + 그룹 레전드 칩 + th title tooltip”로만 해결한다.

[완성 기준]
- 캡처와 유사한 카드/테이블 밀도, 라운드, 보더, 스페이싱을 재현
- 라이트/다크 전환 시 전체 UI가 자연스럽게 바뀜
- ko/zh 전환 시 사이드바/페이지/테이블 컬럼명이 즉시 바뀜(한 줄 유지)

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Implementing theme providers**

I need to implement providers for theme, language, and sidebar. For theme toggling, I'm deciding whether to use a next-themes dependency or go without one. Since they already have a `.dark` variable, I can simply toggle `document.documentElement.classList.toggle('dark')`. The theme will be stored in localStorage as either 'light' or 'dark'. On load, it’s essential to read from localStorage before the first paint to avoid any flash. I might use a script in `app/layout.tsx` to set the initial theme based on preferences.
**Setting up app UI context**

I’m going to default to light for the theme unless there’s something stored. To apply the theme, I’ll add or remove the 'dark' class on `document.documentElement`. I need to provide `toggleTheme` or `setTheme`. 

For language management, I’ll manage states for 'ko' or 'zh', reading from localStorage with 'ko' as the default. I’ll include a toggle function too.

Additionally, I’ll manage whether the sidebar is collapsed, with a boolean state defaulting to false. I should ensure to provide `appUi` context and address SSR mismatches by applying the theme class before hydration, possibly with an inline script later. I'll create `components/providers/app-ui-provider.tsx` for this.
**Creating provider structure**

It seems like the `components.json` alias includes "@/hooks", but there isn’t a `hooks` directory yet, so I'll need to create one. I’ll start with `hooks/use-local-storage-state.ts`, although it could be simple. I also want to create `hooks/useMounted.ts` for theme-specific functionality.

Next, I’ll work on `hooks/use-app-ui.ts`, which will export a `useAppUi` that utilizes context. I’ll also set up `app/providers.tsx` to wrap the root layout with providers. Initially, the root layout just returns children, but I’ll modify it to include `<AppProviders>{children}</AppProviders>` for now. I can always add `AppShell` later. Let’s just keep it straightforward for now!
**Implementing theme initialization**

Since `app/layout.tsx` is a server component, it can indeed import client components, which is great! Now, I need to ensure `AppProviders` uses `useEffect` to interact with the `document`. I also want to implement a `ThemeScript` to set the initial theme and avoid any flash.

I can add an inline script in `app/layout.tsx`, but I’m considering whether Next might block it. Including `<script>` in the `<head>` section is possible, but not widely recommended. A simpler approach could be using `next/script` with `strategy="beforeInteractive"` to run the script before the main paint, keeping everything smooth. Let's go with that!
**Implementing theme initialization script**

I’m opting for a custom implementation for the theme initialization script. It will check for a stored theme in localStorage, defaulting to 'light' if none is found. Based on the theme, it will add or remove the 'dark' class from `document.documentElement`. 

I decided not to incorporate system preferences this time, as it's not necessary. I can include this script before the provider to avoid FOUC. I'll proceed to create `components/providers/app-ui-provider.tsx`, along with the hook, while keeping the script in the layout. It's time to get this organized!</details></think>

---

좋습니다. 이제부터는 **테마(light/dark) + 언어(ko/zh) + 사이드바 접힘**을 전역 상태로 만들고(로컬스토리지 영속), 동시에 초기 로딩 시 **다크 플래시(FOUC)**를 막기 위해 `beforeInteractive` 스크립트로 html에 `.dark`를 먼저 적용하겠습니다.

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Building AppShell Component**

I’m working on implementing the AppShell component, which includes both the Sidebar and Topbar along with the main content. I’m thinking about creating a directory called `components/shell/` or `components/layout/`, so let's decide on that. The AppShell will utilize `useAppUi` for collapsed toggles, and the Topbar will handle theme and language toggles. For the design, I envision using CSS grid to arrange the layout for sidebar and main content. After that, we can integrate AppShell into the top-level layout.
**Finalizing Layout Adjustments**

I’m planning to set the topbar’s background to `bg-card`, and I might want to add some padding to the content with `p-6`. For the dark theme, the background will be dark with the topbar still using `bg-card`. The sidebar will have different widths depending on its state: `w-[205px]` when open and `w-[62px]` when collapsed. 

I’ll implement a sticky sidebar, but I need to consider how sticky positioning works with flex and scrolling. I think using a layout with a full-height container will help keep the topbar fixed while allowing the main content to scroll correctly.
**Designing the Topbar**

I'm currently focusing on the Topbar design, which will be `h-16` high with a bottom border. I plan to incorporate elements like a collapse toggle and a search input on the left side, with notifications on the right. 

I want to create a `TopbarSearch` component that includes an input field and a magnifying icon. To maximize reusability, I think it's best to set up basic `components/ui/button` and `components/ui/input` first. Even though we might not have those components ready yet, I can implement the Topbar with minimal button and input styles. Once that's done, I’ll dive into creating the specific UI components we need.
**Adjusting UI Components**

I’m focusing on adapting the fonts for our UI components. I'll set `font-asia-medium` as the default for buttons and include it in the base class. 

I need to create button variants, such as default, outline, ghost, and possibly secondary, with defined styles for sizing options. Also, I’ll implement input fields using `font-asia-light` and proper borders. For badges, I’ll apply `font-asia-medium` with a text size of `xs`.

I think it makes sense to create `components/ui/button.tsx`, `components/ui/input.tsx`, `components/ui/badge.tsx`, and a simple card component, with various structured elements similar to shadcn. Also, I'm considering adding an avatar component later.
**Implementing the Avatar Component**

I’m thinking it would be straightforward to implement the `Avatar` component. I’ll make it a simple `div` that includes an image and a fallback option, so I won’t be using Radix for this one. This approach keeps it light and easy, while still providing the necessary functionality. I’m ready to start creating these components now!</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Setting up import features**

I’m thinking about importing logos into my project. I’ll be using Next Image and Link for that. I’ll also utilize `usePathname` to activate the functionality properly. It seems like I’ll implement both an expanded group and a collapsed list to organize everything neatly. It’s interesting how these features can enhance the user experience, and I want to ensure everything is set up correctly!
**Implementing sidebar functionality**

I'm working on the sidebar component where I need to import necessary items like Image and Link from Next.js. I’ll also use `usePathname` to maintain navigation context. The sidebar will have a collapsible feature, with state controls imported from my application UI provider. I plan to customize styles for both expanded and collapsed states. I'll ensure the layout is user-friendly, with clear navigation options based on whether the sidebar is collapsed or open.
**Designing sidebar item classes**

I'm focusing on constructing the classes for the sidebar leaf items. I aim to streamline things by defining a base class for alignment and padding, including hover effects. However, I need to adjust the padding left because the border adds additional width, which might affect content alignment.

For collapsed items, using `justify-center` and resetting padding makes sense. I also need to consider displaying a second-level menu, ensuring the design meets the requirement for font size and padding. Maybe I'll show group headers without links but with an icon and label.
**Finalizing sidebar subitem design**

I'm deciding to hide icons for the subitems and just indent them. Normally, DashStack might show small dots, but I think it’s best to keep it clean and simple. I'll implement these subitems as `Link` elements, using `pl-9` for padding and `text-xs` for the font size, without icons. However, in the collapsed state, I will show icons for each leaf item. I also need to include user info at the bottom, but I won't implement a dropdown; just displaying it should suffice.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Implementing a user menu**

I’m looking to create a simple `div` for the user menu that includes relative positioning and a button to toggle its open state. I'll use `useState` for managing the toggle and `useRef` to close the menu when clicking outside of it. The menu items will be Profile, Settings, and Logout, and I'll ensure to include translations in Korean and Chinese. I might also consider adding a user avatar. Time to patch this up!</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Considering routing options**

I’m thinking about how to create a dynamic route, like `[...slug]`, to render a placeholder based on path mapping. They want a menu click to route, but dynamic routing can still be useful. I’m wondering if mapping actions might be overkill, so maybe a simpler solution is to create dedicated page files for each route. There are around 14 leaf pages to make, which I’ll list out. I’ll implement this structure and think about possibly sharing "제작상품" with product-stock.
**Implementing actions per page**

I’ve got the list of actions for each page, like 주문입력 for Excel uploads, and 사입목록 for downloads. For each action, I’ll use lucide icons: `Upload` for uploads, `Download` for downloads, and `Barcode` for barcode prints. I think `Printer` could work too! 

Now, for internationalization, I’ll create translations for these action labels: in Korean and Chinese, like "Excel 上传" for an upload. It looks like I have everything lined up to implement these actions accordingly!
**Implementing page updates**

I’m ready to implement the page updates! First, I need to finalize the page titles, including the Chinese translations. I’ll make sure the menu labels are already set before I dive in. The next step is creating the PageHeader component, which should blend nicely with everything. I’ll patch up the new component file and the corresponding pages. Everything seems organized, so I’m excited to see this come together!</details></think>

**Patching redirect error**

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Updating import method**

I see that the current patch uses require and eslint disables, which isn’t the best approach. Instead, I should use ESM import from 'next/navigation'. It makes sense to update the code to `import { redirect } from "next/navigation";` at the top since that file is a server component, and using import is the right way to go. Let’s open the file to apply the necessary patch correctly!</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Considering internationalization**

I noticed that we used English strings in the dashboard, which ideally should be i18n for internationalization, but it might not be strictly necessary. They mentioned page titles and such, and these are inside cards. We could adjust this later, but it would be better to set it up correctly now. I also need to create stub pages for other routes, which might be numerous, and include minimal content. Let's plan to patch this with multiple Add File hunks.</details></think>

---

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Planning key pages**

I realize we still need to build pages for order-lists and product-stock; these are essential as they correspond to pending tasks. So, I'll create placeholders for these pages as the next step. We haven't made `app/orders/order-lists/page.tsx` yet, but I can create it soon with a full table. The same goes for `app/product-stock/page.tsx`. I think it's best to focus on creating the route pages first to keep our menu organized. After that, we can dive into full implementation and run lints on the new additions later.
**Implementing route pages**

I realize I should eventually mark the routes and pages as a to-do after I implement the order-lists and product-stock pages. Those routes will involve navigation and page titles, which we already have stubs for. So, the plan is to implement the Order Lists and Product Stock pages according to the specs, finalizing the routes. 

Along the way, I might also include the DataTable component and handle i18n translation for the table columns. For this, I’ll create `lib/order-lists-data.ts` for my data, and maybe `lib/format.ts` for currency handling. Now, I’m ready to start on the Order Lists page.
**Structuring order-lists implementation**

For the order-lists, I think implementing everything within the page file might be tricky, so separating it is a better approach. I plan to create a `lib/order-lists.ts` file that includes the `ORDER_LIST_COLUMNS` typed array and the `ORDER_LIST_ROWS` typed array. 

Instead of placing everything in `app/orders/order-lists/order-lists-data.ts`, it's better to use `lib/mock` and create `lib/mock/order-lists.ts`. Now, for the DataTable implementation, it will accept columns and rows, and each column will have various properties like letter, key, group, and labels in different languages. I also want to incorporate group band classes, provide group legend chips, and ensure I have a cell rendering function for the dynamic row fields. It’s quite a job, but I'm ready to dive in!
**Defining types for order lists**

I need to define some types for the order-lists. I’ll create `OrderListColumn`, which includes properties like letter, key, group, and labels in both Korean and Chinese, as well as an example value. Then, I’ll define `OrderListRow` as a record of strings.

After defining these columns as constants, I wonder if the Order Lists page should be a client component. Since it uses `useAppUi` for the language context, it probably should be a client component to allow for instant language changes without a page refresh. To achieve this, I’ll add `'use client'` in `app/orders/order-lists/page.tsx` and ensure it exports the client component so we can work with `useAppUi`.
**Building order-lists components**

Many pages might currently be server components, but since `PageHeader` uses `useAppUi`, it’s a client component, which works fine as long as it’s rendered inside a server page. To make the language toggling effective, I realize that components like the table should also be client-based, so I plan to create the `OrderListsView` as a client component but keep the main page as a server component.

Next, I’ll design the filter bar to resemble DashStack, including a card layout with inline controls and a "Reset Filter" button. I’ll use Card components, Input, and Button elements. For the select dropdowns, I'll create a custom `Select` component and possibly a `Label` component for clarity. 

The filter will include a single date input labeled "Date," as well as selects for order types and statuses. I’ll use ghost buttons for resets to keep it visually pleasing. For the table design, I’m considering group legend chips with badge components and group-specific styles using a utility function.

To enhance user experience, I plan to add styling features like sticky headers and allow for horizontal scrolling. I’ll implement scroll constraints for both vertical and horizontal views while ensuring the first column remains sticky. I think these adjustments will create a clean, user-friendly interface!
**Finalizing cell rendering and data setup**

I realize I need to ensure the sticky cells maintain their background; I'll set `bg` for those and adjust z-index values—`z-20` for table headers (`th`) and `z-10` for table data (`td`). I’m also thinking about adding shadows or borders for visual clarity. 

For the cell rendering, I’ll format dates to `YYYY-MM-DD`, display placeholder images as 32x32 squares, and format URLs with icons that open in new tabs. Currency values will be right-aligned, barcodes will have copy functionality, and empty quantities will show as a muted dash.

Next, for pagination, I’ll reflect something like "Showing 1-12 of 12" with appropriate spacing. I need to create a data file, `lib/mock/order-lists.ts`, with 12 row entries, generating variations for realistic data. Using incremental modifications will help keep things interesting, so I’ll create that now.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Implementing table design**

I’m thinking about how to implement the table design effectively. For the `thead`, I can set the class to `sticky top-0 z-10`, while keeping `th` normal. To ensure compatibility with modern browsers, I’ll make the `th` sticky too. I’ll add `sticky top-0` to `th` for the header and address the first column with `th sticky top-0 left-0 z-30`. For `td`, I’ll make it sticky on the left with `sticky left-0 z-20`. I'm outlining the layout structure as well.
**Refining table design**

When dealing with the table, I find it easier to apply `border-b` directly to `td` with `border-b border-border/70`. For the `td`, I’ll also use `px-3 py-2` and set the text size to `text-xs`. It’s important to allow horizontal scrolling, so I’ll add a wrapper with `overflow-auto`. I should set the `table` class to `min-w-max` for content width and possibly a `bg-card`. 

Now, for the sticky first column, I’ll focus on column A only. Next, I’ll implement the `renderCell(col, row)` function for different key values to handle formatted dates, placeholders, and icons accordingly.
**Designing table formatting**

For the wrap around `a`, I’m considering a class of `flex items-center gap-1 text-primary hover:underline`, but to keep it minimal, I might stick with `text-foreground` combined with an icon and `hover:text-primary`. I could also use `text-muted-foreground hover:text-foreground` to show the icon and truncated text.

For currency formatting, I’ll use `formatCurrencyKRW(row[col.key])` for keys 'cg' and add prefixes. For 'co', I’ll apply `formatCurrencyCNY`. Numeric values, such as cp, cq, and others should be right-aligned for amounts and centered for counts. Finally, for 'caa', I’ll implement a monospace display with a copy button, and for defaults, I'll show values or `—` in muted text.
**Implementing pagination and filtering**

I'm thinking about the filter UI; instead of implementing an actual filter, I'll just store the state for now. For the pagination component, I plan to place it at the bottom of the card. I’ll create a `div` that displays something like "1-12 / 12" with the corresponding buttons. I'll use the `Button` component with `variant="outline"` and `size="sm"` for a nice look. Finally, I'll create the file `components/order-lists/order-lists-table.tsx` to keep everything organized.</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Analyzing table hover functionality**

I’m looking at the table setup and noticing `hover:bg-accent/30` on rows, but it seems like cell backgrounds might override that. The `meta.bandClass` sets a specific background on each cell, and since those aren’t transparent, the row hover won’t show through. I wonder if using `group` and `group-hover` on `td` elements could help. The sticky header uses `meta.bandClass` too, which is good, but there might be layering problems with different backgrounds. Alright, I’ll move on to the order-lists page file next!
**Planning order lists page**

I'm considering adding the order lists table inside another Card. I think I’ll create `app/orders/order-lists/page.tsx` as a server component, but I'm debating whether to keep the state in the client. The PageHeader and OrderListsTable are client components, so making the whole page server-oriented could help reduce the client bundle size. However, I feel like it could still work as a server component with static inputs. Ultimately, I think I’ll go for an interactive filter bar, which means implementing it as a client component for better functionality.
**Creating order lists page**

I'm all set to create `app/orders/order-lists/page.tsx` with `'use client'` to manage filter state and the reset functionality. I have a basic structure in mind. I’ll import a bunch of components like `PageHeader`, `Card`, and `OrderListsTable` to keep everything organized. I’ll also handle different states for date, order type, and status. I noticed that `CardContent` has `p-5` applied by default, so I’ll need to manage that to suit our layout better. Let's get this implemented!
**Designing the filter bar**

I think the filter bar should resemble a dashboard, possibly placed inside the same Card at the top of the table, but I could also use a separate Card if needed. I want to include a "Reset Filter" button, probably styled as a ghost button. For label styling, I’ll go with `text-xs font-asia-medium text-muted-foreground mb-1`, and for inputs, I’ll use `font-asia-light`. The reset button will feature an icon and a label. I also want the table header to be sticky within its wrapper. Time to implement this!</details></think>

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
**Implementing product stock page**

I've implemented the order-lists page, and now I need to ensure the filter bar UI matches the categories: Date, Order Type, Order Status, and Reset Filter. Next up is the Product Stock page. I’ll create the `app/product-stock/page.tsx` for client use, with a search bar at the top right and a table featuring thumbnails and color dots with tooltips. I’ll also set up `components/product-stock/product-stock-table.tsx` and create dummy data for `PRODUCT_STOCK_ROWS`. I'll define a product type and use a placeholder for images, rendering a grid of color dots based on hex values with action icons.
**Adding search feature**

I want the top right search to resemble DashStack with a "Search..." input. They mentioned it should be in the "상단 우측 검색," indicating it should be placed in the right slot of the page header. I’ll utilize the `rightSlot` feature of our PageHeader to implement this. This seems like a straightforward way to integrate the search input, so I'll go ahead with that plan. It feels good to be making progress!
**Building the Product Stock page**

For the Product Stock page, I'm setting up the basic structure with imports and defining the `PRODUCTS`. I’ll use the `PageHeader` component for titles and actions, and I'll incorporate the search input in the right slot. I think I should style the table similar to DashStack, with small text, borders, and maybe sticky headers, although I’m not sure if that’s strictly necessary. I'll also add row hover highlights and include columns for Image, Product Name, Category, Price, Piece, Available Color, and Action. Plus, I'll implement i18n labels for those columns.
**Formatting product details**

I’m gearing up to format the product details for the table. The price will be formatted using the Intl API, which should make it look nice. For the piece quantity, I’ll keep it as a simple number. The available colors will be rendered as dots, which sounds visually appealing. I also want to include action icons for user interactions. To start, I’ll create the `lib/mock/product-stock.ts` file first to set up the necessary mock data. Let's get that done!</details></think>
